prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(1-0) NGC 3626 Band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to map the 12CO(1-0) line in the early-type galaxy NGC 3626. Our goal is to obtain CO data cubes with superior resolution sensitivity, and velocity resolution to that already obtained with CARMA.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will observe the 12CO(1-0) line in baseband 1. We will use the 468 MHz FDM correlator mode which will give 0.6 km/s channels and a full velocity range of 1225 km/s. The velocity range is large enough to cover the 350 km/s linewidth of NGC 3626 and for continuum subtraction. We intend to average in the spectral domain to make cubes of 5 km/s for our analysis. For NGC 3626 the 5 km/s velocity resolution will allow us to get 70 channels across the line with a snr of ~5 in each channel.
We will also configure the other 3 basebands, one in the USB and two in the LSB, using the 31.250 MHz FDM correlator modes to search for radio continuum associated with the target.

The ALMA primary beamwidth for the requested sky frequency is 50.8 arcseconds. The largest diamater of the CO emission (40 arcseconds) for NGC 3626 fits within the ALMA primary beam. The largest angular scale of structures inside the CARMA channel maps is ~25 arcseconds (2.4 kpc at a distance of 19.4 Mpc). The smallest angular scale of structures inside the CARMA channel maps is ~5 arcsec. Thus the requested 1.5" angular resolution (~ 0.1 kpc) will give at least a few beams across detected emission on all scales. This will allow us to estimate with high precision the radial distribution of the CO/H2 surface density which is needed to test the physical and emperical models of molecular formation in early-type galaxies.

Previous CARMA observations show that NGC 3626 has no detectable radio continuum associated with it at this frequency. Therefore, there is no continuum flux density to include.
For NGC 3626 the peak 12CO(1-0) intensity in a 25 km/s channel of the 3.9"x3.0 resolution CARMA data is 70 mJy/beam. If we conservatively assume that the peak intensity is distributed over five ALMA 1.5" synthesized beams the peak becomes 14 mJy/beam. A signal to noise ratio of 5 gives an rms noise of 2.8 mJy/beam. Using the ASC we find 16.6 minutes on target is required to reach this rms level in a 5 km/s channel. An additional 22 minutes of calibration/overhead is required giving a total track time of 38.6 min.
Channel sizes of 5 km/s will allow us to derive good estimates of the cold gas velocity dispersion from KinMS modeling (Davis et al. 2013), and the snr of 5 will hopefully help us to detect low level CO emission if it exists. The signal to noise reached in the proposed observations is a factor of two better than the existing CARMA observations.
A channel size of 5 km/s will allow us to derive good estimates of the cold gas velocity dispersion from KinMS modeling (Davis et al. 2013), and the snr of 5 will hopefully help us to detect low level CO emission if it exists. The signal to noise reached in the proposed observations is a factor of five better than the existing CARMA oservations.
The cold gas surface desnity at which HI transitions to H2 is predicted to be ~10 Msol/pc^2. A line detected at 4 sigma over two channels will have an integrated intensity of 112 Jy/beam km/s. For a 1.5" beam and assuming a CO-H2 conversion factor of 3.2 Msun/pc2 (K km/s)^-1, this 112 mJy/beam km/s will yield an H2 surface density of ~6.0 Msun/pc2. Thus, with the proposed observations we should be able to probe the HI-H2 transition region in this target.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Knowledge of the amount of cold gas in the the molecular phase versus the atomic phase is an important constraint for theoretical models of star-formation and galaxy evolution. This is especially true for early-type galaxies whose evolution is thought to be drive in part by the acquisition and transformation of cold gas into new stars. We propose to map the 12CO(1-0) line in four Atlas3D early-type galaxies. Our main goal is to obtain CO data cubes with superior resolution, sensitivity, and velocity resolution to that already obtained with the combined Array for Millimeter Wave astronomy (CARMA). The ALMA maps produced from the propsoed observations in conjunction with closely matching VLA+WSRT HI maps will allow us for the first time to test empirical and theoretical models of molecule formation in early-type galaxies.
